scenes.on_screen_action: Quick zoom-in on narrator's face (or animated brain emoji). Bold neon title slams in. Background: glitchy brain-network animation. Very fast cuts. Insert hook text in top-left. Beat drop sound.
scenes.dialogue_vo: What if a computer could 'learn' like your brain? Here's how — in 60 seconds.
scenes.on_screen_text:
What if a computer could 'learn' like your brain?
Here's how — 60s crash course
Yapay Zeka (YZ) = makin' decisions + learning

scenes.on_screen_action: Drake Hotline Bling split: top 'reject' panel shows clueless random guessing (grainy), bottom 'approve' panel shows neat neural net graphic glowing. Add quick text pop on each panel (use provided meme text).
scenes.dialogue_vo: AI isn't magic — it's techniques. Don't just guess weights; use Delta/backprop and structured learning.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Don't: guess weights
Do: Delta / Backprop
Quick note: ANNs inspired by the brain — learn from data

scenes.on_screen_action: Fast montage: icons for Expert Systems, Genetic Algorithms, Fuzzy Logic, Intelligent Agents pop in with captions. Each icon pulses as a one-line definition appears.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Other AI tools: expert systems mimic experts, genetic algorithms evolve solutions, fuzzy logic handles uncertainty, and intelligent agents act autonomously.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Expert Systems → mimic experts
Genetic Algorithms → evolve solutions
Fuzzy Logic → handle uncertainty
Intelligent Agents → make independent decisions

scenes.on_screen_action: Two Buttons meme (sweating hand reaching): left button 'Supervised (labels)', right 'Unsupervised (clusters)'. A sticky note underneath: 'Reinforcement = rewards' flashes. Quick overlay: 'Which to pick? Map your problem.'
scenes.dialogue_vo: Labels, clusters, or rewards — choose a learning strategy: supervised uses labels, unsupervised finds clusters, reinforcement learns from rewards.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Problem: pick learning type
Button A: Supervised (labels)
Button B: Unsupervised (clusters)
Side note: Reinforcement = rewards
Study prompt: map your problem

scenes.on_screen_action: Animated neuron network. Highlight a single neuron and show weight arrows changing color as a training example flows through. Tiny caption: 'Watch one neuron change its mind.' Use Surprised Pikachu reaction when weight update improves output.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Watch one neuron change its mind: inputs -> weighted sum -> activation. The weights shift to make predictions better.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Input x -> weight w -> sum -> activation
Weight update = learning
Watch: loss ↓ → neuron happier

scenes.on_screen_action: Split-screen: left shows 'Hebbian' with retro brain GIF, right shows 'Delta (Backprop)' with terminal snippet. Add Distracted Boyfriend meme overlay: boyfriend labeled 'Me: choosing a rule', girlfriend 'Delta (accurate)', other 'Hebbian (fun)'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: How do weights change? Quick trio: Hebbian (fire together, wire together), Delta/backprop (error-driven), Kohonen (winner-take-all for maps).
scenes.on_screen_text:
Hebbian: Δw = η * output * input
Delta (Backprop): Δw = η * (target - output) * input
Kohonen: Winner updates toward input
Meme: Me: choosing a rule | Girlfriend: Delta (accurate) | Other: Hebbian (fun)

scenes.on_screen_action: Show tiny code block in a terminal window (monospace). Rapidly type the delta rule in Python, then flash a one-line Keras example. Use a glowing arrow showing 'train'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Here's the Delta update as code — mini demo you can copy-paste.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Python — Delta update example:

w += lr * (target - output) * x

Keras quick build:
from tensorflow import keras
model = keras.Sequential([keras.layers.Dense(16, activation='relu'),
                           keras.layers.Dense(1, activation='sigmoid')])
model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='binary_crossentropy')
# model.fit(X, y, epochs=10)

scenes.on_screen_action: Expanding Brain / Galaxy Brain progression graphic: Linear models -> Single-layer perceptron -> Multi-layer NN -> Deep learning + backprop. Each step lights up with pros/cons appearing to the side. Add small tradeoff tag.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Model evolution: linear → perceptron → deep nets. More power but less explainability — a tradeoff.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Linear models
Single-layer perceptron
Multi-layer NN
Deep learning + backprop
Tradeoff: power vs explainability
Tip: visualize weights to debug

scenes.on_screen_action: Mocking Spongebob roast sequence: text mocking the idea 'They’re tiny brains!' then a factual overlay. Use red stamp 'MYTH' then 'FACT' slide in.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Myth: ANNs think like us. Fact: they learn patterns from data — not consciousness. Patterns, not minds.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Myth: "ANNs think like us"
Mock: "They’re tiny brains!"
Fact: They learn patterns
Patterns, Not Minds
Save for review

scenes.on_screen_action: Quick list of limitations with icons: chip for hardware, jigsaw for architecture, blurred glass for interpretability. Add Surprised Pikachu when 'explainability' is called out as a problem.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Limits? Yes: hardware dependence, choosing the right structure, and poor interpretability of decisions.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Limitations:
• Hardware dependence (compute, memory)
• Hard to pick network structure
• Low interpretability (black box)
Watch out when stakes are high!

scenes.on_screen_action: Fast montage of applications: stock chart, MRI scan, robot arm, factory sensor. Overlay quick captions for each use-case. Add small code snippet for installing TensorFlow in a terminal.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Applications? Everywhere: finance, engineering, medicine, pattern recognition — ANNs handle complex, uncertain, incomplete data.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Applications:
• Finance (predictive models)
• Medicine (disease detection)
• Engineering (control systems)
• Pattern recognition (images, speech)

Terminal:
pip install tensorflow
python train_model.py

scenes.on_screen_action: Final rapid-fire recap — 3 bullet flashcards. Insert CTA with subscribe/follow icons and a challenge: 'Try mapping your problem to a learning type'. End with neon outro and upbeat sound.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Recap: AI = decision + learning; ANNs learn patterns via supervised/unsupervised/reinforcement; rules (Hebb/Delta/Kohonen) change weights; pros, cons, big impact. Try it yourself!
scenes.on_screen_text:
Recap:
1) YZ = karar verme + öğrenme
2) YSA = örüntü öğrenir
3) Öğrenme: Supervised | Unsupervised | Reinforcement
4) Kurallar: Hebb, Delta, Kohonen

Try: Map your problem → pick a learning type
Call to action: Like / Follow for deep dives
Save to study

voice_timing.text: What if a computer could 'learn' like your brain? Here's how — in 60 seconds.
AI isn't magic — it's techniques. Don't just guess weights; use Delta/backprop and structured learning.
Other AI tools: expert systems mimic experts, genetic algorithms evolve solutions, fuzzy logic handles uncertainty, and intelligent agents act autonomously.
Labels, clusters, or rewards — choose a learning strategy: supervised uses labels, unsupervised finds clusters, reinforcement learns from rewards.
Watch one neuron change its mind: inputs -> weighted sum -> activation. The weights shift to make predictions better.
How do weights change? Quick trio: Hebbian (fire together, wire together), Delta/backprop (error-driven), Kohonen (winner-take-all for maps).
Here's the Delta update as code — mini demo you can copy-paste.
Model evolution: linear → perceptron → deep nets. More power but less explainability — a tradeoff.
Myth: ANNs think like us. Fact: they learn patterns from data — not consciousness. Patterns, not minds.
Limits? Yes: hardware dependence, choosing the right structure, and poor interpretability of decisions.
Applications? Everywhere: finance, engineering, medicine, pattern recognition — ANNs handle complex, uncertain, incomplete data.
Recap: AI = decision + learning; ANNs learn patterns via supervised/unsupervised/reinforcement; rules (Hebb/Delta/Kohonen) change weights; pros, cons, big impact. Try it yourself!
